article.title: Helium ignition in rotating magnetized CO white dwarfs leading to fast and faint rather than classical type Ia supernovae

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the rotational velocity profile of two model sequences (Lm20510-5 and Lm21010-5) at different times during their evolution. What is the primary effect of the Tayler-Spruit mechanism on the rotational profile of the white dwarfs?
choices: The Tayler-Spruit mechanism significantly enhances differential rotation, creating a steep velocity gradient in the outer layers.
The Tayler-Spruit mechanism has little to no effect on the rotational profile, leaving a large gradient throughout the evolution.
The Tayler-Spruit mechanism induces a state close to solid body rotation, significantly reducing any initial velocity gradient.
The Tayler-Spruit mechanism only affects the core of the white dwarf, leaving the envelope with a steep velocity gradient.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 displays the surface velocity of four model sequences at different initial luminosities, normalized to the critical surface velocity. What trend can be observed regarding the spin-up of white dwarfs with different initial masses?
choices: Less massive white dwarfs spin up more slowly than more massive ones due to their higher rotational inertia.
The initial luminosity has a stronger effect on the spin-up time than the initial mass of the white dwarf.
Less massive white dwarfs spin up faster than more massive ones due to their lower rotational inertia.
The spin-up time is independent of both the initial luminosity and the initial mass of the white dwarf.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 presents the temperature-density profiles of a rotating and a non-rotating WD with 0.54 MâŠ™. What is the primary difference in the amount of helium accreted at the point of helium ignition between the two models?
choices: The non-rotating model accumulates a significantly larger amount of helium due to enhanced compressional heating.
The rotating model accumulates a significantly larger amount of helium due to the suppression of differential rotation by the Tayler-Spruit mechanism.
The rotating model accumulates a significantly smaller amount of helium due to centrifugal force decreasing the density and thus delaying ignition.
Both models accumulate approximately the same amount of helium, with rotational effects having a negligible impact on the ignition conditions.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 7 shows the total masses of all computed model sequences at the point of helium ignition with respect to the mass accretion rate. Which of the following statements is true about the impact of initial luminosity on the final helium shell mass?
choices: Higher initial luminosities consistently lead to larger helium shell masses at ignition across all accretion rates and initial masses.
Initial luminosity has a negligible impact on the final helium shell mass, with the accretion rate being the dominant factor.
Lower initial luminosities lead to larger helium shell masses at ignition, particularly at low accretion rates.
The impact of initial luminosity is complex and depends on the interplay between the mass accretion rate and the initial mass of the white dwarf.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 12 displays the density at the point of ignition (Pign) as a function of the mass accretion rate. What is the key difference in ignition densities between rotating and non-rotating models?
choices: Rotating models exhibit significantly lower ignition densities compared to non-rotating models.
Rotating models exhibit significantly higher ignition densities compared to non-rotating models.
Both rotating and non-rotating models show similar ignition densities, with the mass accretion rate being the primary influence.
Ignition density is independent of both rotation and the mass accretion rate.
